title: 111_s591
content: The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 establishes a commission for these purposes. The Commission is established to evaluate improvements in the US approach to radioactive waste management if the Yucca Mountain repository is not operational. It will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for managing defense waste, spent nuclear fuel, and commercial radioactive waste. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various leaders in consultation with relevant committees. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by different leaders in consultation with relevant committees. One member is appointed jointly by the majority leader of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Qualifications for appointees include restrictions on involvement in high-level radioactive waste activities and government affiliations. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various leaders with specific qualifications. Members must be prominent US citizens with expertise in relevant fields. All members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment, with the Chairperson being appointed under subsection (a)(5). The Commission must start operations promptly after the Act's enactment. The Commission, comprised of 9 members with specific qualifications, must start operations promptly after the Act's enactment. Meetings will be called by the Chairperson or majority of members, with a quorum of five members required. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Commission is tasked with evaluating alternatives to the Federal Government's spent fuel and high-level waste strategies, including transferring responsibility to a Government corporation with necessary authority and funding for storage and management. Cost-sharing options between the Federal Government are also considered. The Commission is evaluating alternatives for storage and management of high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel, including cost-sharing options with private industry. This includes establishing centralized interim storage facilities and researching advanced fuel cycle technologies to prevent weapons proliferation. The Department of Energy is tasked with transferring title to spent nuclear fuel inventories at reactor sites for future management. This includes transferring spent nuclear fuel inventories to at-reactor dry casks to ensure public safety and security. The Department of Energy is responsible for transferring spent nuclear fuel inventories to at-reactor dry casks for public safety and security. The Commission is also tasked with consulting various stakeholders for permanent disposal solutions and management strategies for defense wastes. The Commission, in consultation with various stakeholders, will submit recommendations on the disposition of fees charged to nuclear energy ratepayers and analyze the financial impacts on the Federal Government's contractual liability under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982. A final report will be submitted to Congress. The Commission will submit a final report to Congress as required by the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The Commission will submit a final report to Congress as required by the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather evidence, and administer oaths. It can also enter into contracts to fulfill its duties and obtain information from federal agencies for the purposes of the Act. The Federal Government is required to provide information, suggestions, estimates, and statistics to the Commission as requested. The Commission and its staff must handle and disseminate information in accordance with applicable laws. Assistance can be sought from federal agencies as needed. The Commission can receive administrative support from the General Services Administration and other federal agencies as needed. They are authorized to use postal services like other government departments. The Federal Advisory Committee Act applies to the Commission, and they can receive staff support as needed. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint staff and set their compensation without following certain federal employment rules. The staff director and personnel can be federal employees. The staff director and personnel of the Commission can be federal employees under specific sections of the United States Code. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their rights and privileges. The Commission may also procure consultant services. The Commission may procure consultant services from experts and consultants at rates not exceeding the daily rate paid to a person at level IV of the Executive Schedule under section 5315 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 9. Compensation; Travel Expenses. Each Commission member may be compensated at the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for a position at level IV of the Executive Schedule. Travel expenses, including per diem, are allowed for Commission members while performing duties. SEC. 10. Security Clearances. SEC. 10. SECURITY CLEARANCES. The Federal agencies will cooperate with the Commission to provide security clearances to members and staff as needed. No access to classified information will be granted without appropriate clearances. SEC. 11. REPORTS. SEC. 11. REPORTS. The Commission will release an interim report for public comment within a year and a final report to Congress within two years, including findings, conclusions, recommendations, and dissenting opinions. Public comments will be considered in the final report. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the Act, with funds available until expended. The Commission's authority terminates 180 days after the final report submission, allowing for administrative activities during this period.
